entry.title: Combined summary - consensus rule change for TX fee safety
entry.summary: A recent Bitcoin transaction involving a 15 BTC (worth approximately $130,000) fee has sparked discussions about the need for safety rules in handling transaction fees during hard forks. Alice Wonder suggested implementing a safety rule for transaction fees in the next hard fork. Two proposed solutions were given to prevent incidents like this from happening again: TX fee may not be larger than the sum of outputs or TX fee per byte may not be larger than 4X largest fee per byte in the previous block.Henning Kopp agreed with the idea of implementing the rule as a safety mechanism in the client rather than doing a hard fork. Jorge Tim贸n also suggested that such a check already exists, but it can be improved, and it may be more appropriate to implement it at the wallet layer. There is no clear consensus on how to proceed, with some suggesting that such rules should be implemented in the client as a safety mechanism rather than through a hard fork.The incident with the 15 BTC fee has sparked discussions about the need for safety rules and limitations on transaction fees during hard forks. Some experts believe that implementing safety rules could help avoid such incidents in the future and increase confidence in using Bitcoin. However, there is no clear consensus on how to proceed, with some suggesting that such rules should be implemented in the client as a safety mechanism rather than through a hard fork.Bitcoin Core has implemented a safety limit of 10000 times the minimum relay fee, also known as an "absurd fee" limit, to prevent large transaction fees. There is also a user configurable option called -maxtxfee to limit fees set by the wallet, which currently defaults to 0.1 BTC. However, there are legitimate use cases where one would want to pay a large transaction fee, such as convenience for miners to collect fees instead of sending back change on their own transactions. Nevertheless, it is planned for Bitcoin Core 0.13 to use -maxtxfee for both the wallet and the RPC interface.In addition, a user discussed the possibility of a client not adjusting the transaction fee and needing to manually set it in order to get the transaction into a block. They disagreed with implementing limitations on the size of the transaction fee, stating that such checks should be done by transaction creation clients or that nodes could have the option to not accept transactions with high fees into their mempool based on policy. They also stated that these limitations should not be part of the consensus layer.The incident of the 15 BTC fee has raised concerns among some experts about the scalability of Bitcoin and other cryptocurrencies, with some arguing that high transaction fees could hamper wider adoption. However, others argue that the incident is an isolated one and should not be seen as indicative of broader issues with the cryptocurrency ecosystem. Overall, it serves as a reminder of the challenges facing the cryptocurrency industry as it seeks to grow and mature in the years ahead.
